# Draft:The German Fusiliers of Charleston in the American Revolution

In May, 1775, approximately one month after the battles of Lexington and Concord, five citizens of Charleston, South Carolina, formed the German Fusiliers. The five organizers were: Alexander Gillon, Peter Boquet, Michael Kalteissen, William Livingston and Gideon Dupont. Gillon and Kalteissen would later resign in the latter part of 1777. Gillon became commander of the vessels of war for South Carolina and Kalteissen would be appointed as the Provincial Army's Wagon-master-general for the state. They enlisted the following men, who became the German Fusiliers. The most noteworthy involvement of the German Fusiliers in the American Revolution was their participation in the battles of Port Royal Island and the Siege of Savannah.

Following defeat at Savannah and their return to Charleston, the Fusiliers were forced to give up their weapons and disband, but reassembled after the war and continued serving as a military unit for over 100 years.
During George Washington's visit to Charleston in May of 1791, the Fusiliers participated in several events celebrating the general's visit.
